edge: Riley is the main character of the movie, and Inside Out represents the five emotions (joy, sadness, anger, disgust, and fear) that control her thoughts and actions.
Pete Docter is the director of Inside Out. The movie's concept was conceived by him after observing changes in his daughter's personality as she grew older.
Amy Poehler voices Riley in the movie. Riley is the main character and represents a young girl who is going through changes as her family relocates.

Joy and sadness are two of the five emotions that control Riley's thoughts and actions. They sometimes have conflicting opinions on how to handle situations, but they both play important roles in Riley's emotional well-being.
Ronnie del Carmen co-directed Inside Out with Pete Docter. He worked closely with Docter to develop the story and characters, and also consulted psychologists and neuroscientists to ensure accuracy.
Phyllis Smith voices Sadness in the movie. She is one of the five emotions that control Riley's thoughts and actions, and she often finds herself at odds with Joy.
Richard Kind voices Anger in the movie. He is one of the five emotions that control Riley's thoughts and actions, and he sometimes has a hard time controlling his temper.
Bill Hader voices Fear in the movie. He is one of the five emotions that control Riley's thoughts and actions, and he sometimes has a hard time facing his fears.
Mindy Kaling voices Disgust in the movie. She is one of the five emotions that control Riley's thoughts and actions, and she sometimes has a hard time dealing with unpleasant situations.
Kaitlyn Dias voices young Riley in the movie. She is the main character at the beginning of the story, before her family relocates.
Diane Lane voices Riley's mother in the movie. She is a significant figure in Riley's life, and her actions often have an impact on Riley's emotions.
Kyle MacLachlan voices Riley's father in the movie. He is a significant figure in Riley's life, and his actions often have an impact on Riley's emotions.

Memories are stored as colored orbs in the mind of Riley Andersen, and sent into long-term memory each night.
At age 11, Riley moves from Minnesota to San Francisco for her father's new job.
Riley moves from Minnesota to San Francisco for her father's new job.
Riley's father has a new job, causing Riley to move to San Francisco.
The new house is mentioned as being cramped and old in the context.
The pizza parlor only serves pizza topped with broccoli, which Riley dislikes.
Riley experiences poor memories associated with Joy due to Sadness's actions.
Sadness retroactively saddens joyous memories, causing Riley to cry in front of her class and Sadness's first sad core memory.
Joy tries to dispose of the memory using a pneumatic tube, but accidentally knocks loose the other core memories during a struggle with Sadness.
The core memories are dislodged and subsequently sucked out of Headquarters due to Joy's actions and Sadness's interference.
In the absence of Joy, Anger tries to make happy core memories, but the results are disastrous, distancing Riley from her parents, peers, and hobbies.
In the absence of Joy, Fear tries to make happy core memories, but the results are disastrous, distancing Riley from her parents, peers, and hobbies.
In the absence of Joy, Disgust tries to make happy core memories, but the results are disastrous, distancing Riley from her parents, peers, and hobbies.
Anger gradually causes Riley's personality islands to crumble and fall into the 'Memory Dump', where things fade to non-existence as they are forgotten.

Navigating the vast long-term memory area, Joy and Sadness encounter Bing Bong, Riley's imaginary friend, who suggests riding the 'train of thought' back to Headquarters. Anger, intending to restore Riley's happiness, convinces Disgust and Fear that Riley should run away to Minnesota, where her happy memories were formed. After several adventures and mishaps, Joy, Sadness, and Bing Bong catch the train, but it is entirely derailed when another island collapses.

Anger, intending to restore Riley's happiness, convinces Disgust and Fear that Riley should run away to Minnesota, where her happy memories were formed. After several adventures and mishaps, Joy, Sadness, and Bing Bong catch the train, but it is entirely derailed when another island collapses.

Joy breaks down crying and she discovers a sad memory of losing a hockey game that turned happy when Riley's parents and friends comforted her, and realizes Sadness's purpose in alerting others when Riley is emotionally overwhelmed and needs help. Joy and Bing Bong try to use his song-fueled wagon rocket to escape the Memory Dump, but are unable to fully ascend due to their combined weight.

Bing Bong jumps out of the wagon to save Joy, and fades away in the Memory Dump, forgotten.

In early versions of the film, surprise was considered as one of the emotions. However, due to its similarity with fear, it was removed from the final list.

Ekman supplied a list of emotions, including anger, fear, sadness, disgust, contempt, surprise, and happiness, to the film's production team. Docter then decided to remove surprise due to its similarity with fear and renamed happiness as Optimism, which later became Joy.

During the film's five-and-a-half year development process, Chief Creative Officer John Lasseter offered little input due to his focus on restructuring Walt Disney Animation Studios. This was the first Pixar film to be produced without the involvement of Steve Jobs, who had died in 2011.
Ralph Eggleston, Pixar's production designer since 1992, stated that the film's development process was the hardest and longest he had ever worked on.
In 2010, Docter and the filmmaking team met to discuss aspects of Inside Out.
Docter and the filmmaking team met to discuss aspects of Inside Out, including its setting, rules, and reels.

due to that sport's popularity in Minnesota, Del Carmen had the idea of making Riley an avid ice-hockey player.
Screenwriter Michael Arndt spent a year on the script before leaving the project in early 2011.
Along with Docter, Josh Cooley and Meg LeFauve were credited as screenwriters for its rewrites.

Research found that females aged 11 to 17 were more attuned to expressions and emotions than younger girls. This discovery led to the decision that Riley, the protagonist of Inside Out, was not just any main character but specifically a girl.
Inside Out's focus is on Riley, a girl. Because of this, the lead emotion character was assigned as female to reflect Riley's gender.
To promote diverse input, Docter decided that some of the emotion characters in Inside Out were assigned as male, while others were assigned as female.

The creative leaders at Pixar's 'brains trust' spent over three years improving the dinnertime scene in Inside Out to ensure that it remained engaging and entertaining for audiences, while also advancing the story and humor.
As an intangible character, Joy is vulnerable and unapologetically positive because she represents the emotion of happiness in Riley's mind.
Joy's displeasure in Inside Out's design team's research led to a deeper exploration of her personality traits, which were found to be tomboyish and mischievous by designer Albert Lozano.

The concept of personality islands in Inside Out's development integrates the mind world's geography and story by allowing Riley's unique personality traits to be represented as distinct islands within her mind.

Richard Kind defined his character, Bing Bong, in Inside Out's development as 'the fading of childhood,' as Bing Bong represents the memories and experiences that Riley is forgetting as she grows older.

In one instance during Inside Out's development, the characters cultivated ideas after falling to 'Idea Fields,' which emerged as a plot idea when the original idea of Riley wanting the lead role in a Thanksgiving Day pageant was found to be too unfamiliar.

In another instance during Inside Out's development, Bing Bong recruited at a large, exiled entourage of characters from Riley's childhood, as this idea emerged when the team was seeking something to replace the plot idea of Riley wanting the lead role in a Thanksgiving Day pageant.
In October 2011, Diane Disney Miller convinced Pete Docter to reduce Inside Out's distractions and reprioritize the story.
The design team in Inside Out's development researched more of Riley's personality's distinct directions after Pete Docter became concerned over Joy's displeasure.
Designer Albert Lozano found that Joy, as a tomboyish character in Inside Out's development, was tomboyish and mischievous.
The idea of Joy's potential to excessively manipulate youth persisted in Inside Out's development, setting off Riley's 'social storms'.
Pete Docter became concerned over Joy's displeasure in Inside Out's development.

Initially, Joy and Fear got lost together in an early version of the film, but this was deemed problematic by director Pete Docter. Instead, Sadness replaced Fear to have a 'much juicier' role, as Docter believed that Joy's interaction with Sadness would develop her characterization before deciding to integrate emotions and relationships within the film.

Director Pete Docter altered an altercation between Joy and Sadness due to a lack of emotional ending. As a result, Islands of Friendship and Personality became Joy and Sadness's outings in the film to maintain its continuity.

Phyllis Smith, who was initially concerned about her attempt to voice a role in an animated film, was cast as Sadness after Rivera watched a lunch scene in Bad Teacher (2011) and said, 'I think we found our Sadness'. Smith saw her natural voice following her first recording session.
Poehler was the last character to be cast in the emotions film.

Actress Mindy Kaling voiced the character of Disgust in the movie Inside Out. She attended six recording sessions within four hours to voice the character before being cast in the role.
Comedian Lewis Black exemplified the character of Anger in the movie Inside Out. The filmmakers cast him after keeping him in mind, having heard his distinctive voice.
Actress Kaitlyn Dias was cast as Riley in the movie Inside Out. The filmmakers described her performance as 'touching' and praised its 'heartbreaking honesty.'

Actor Bill Hader played the character of Fear in the movie Inside Out. Before his stay on set ended, he contacted Tina Fey and revealed that his role was secret, reaffirming his involvement in the movie Inside Out.

Lin focused on emphasizing the cinematography in Inside Out, creating a visual language with unique camera styles to depict the mind world and real world.
The mind world's layout and cinematography were influenced by Casablanca (1942).
Inside Out's use of scale progressions supported the characterizations by allowing for a visual representation of the main characters' perspectives in the world.
The use of scale progressions in Inside Out also served as a way to stage the story, allowing for a clear visual representation of the narrative's structure.
Additionally, scale progressions were utilized in Inside Out to frame the film's theme by visually illustrating the emotional journey of the main characters.
The main characters Riley and Joy also had arcs that were supported by the use of scale progressions, as their changing perspectives were visually represented through size changes.

Inside Out's crew utilized cameras with attached sensors to capture rough and physical footage that was later improved in the film. This technology allowed for a more realistic representation of the characters' movements within their environment.
A human-machine system was created to allow for the interactions between each person and Inside Out's environment, assigning each performance to interact with the scenes.
Virtual ones were blocked using Layout before being animated in order to better visualize their movements and interactions within the scenes of the film.

Inside Out was premiered at the El Capitan Theatre in Hollywood, Los Angeles on June 8.

During its opening weekend in the United States and Canada, Inside Out grossed $90.4 million across 3,946 theaters, becoming the first Pixar film not to debut at number one, but instead debuting at number two behind Jurassic World ($106.6 million). This revenue included $3.7 million from Thursday night previews. The weekend-total figure made Inside Out the first Pixar film not to debut at number one, the biggest number-two debut of all time (surpassing The Day After Tomorrow), and the largest opening weekend for any original film (surpassing Avatar).
Inside Out's successful opening was attributed to its mostly female audience.
Approximately 71 percent of the viewers were families.
The successful opening was attributed to its Cannes premiere.
During the COVID-19 pandemic, restrictions on cinemas resulted in the closure of many theaters. However, Pixar's animated film Inside Out returned to 442 drive-in theaters and grossed $340,000.
The film 'Inside Out' grossed a total of $858.8 million globally.
Inside Out grossed $11.7 million in China during its opening weekend.
Outside the U.S. And Canada, Inside Out grossed $40.3 million during its opening weekend in 37 markets.
The top-grossing markets for Inside Out were China, the United Kingdom, Mexico, Russia, Italy, Germany, and South Korea.
Inside Out was the first Pixar film to gross over one billion rubles in Russia.
Inside Out grossed $59.4 million in the United Kingdom, making it the film's highest-grossing market.
